dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, so, big news this week from the world of, uh, Elon Musk and space. Starlink, his satellite internet project, is in the headlines again.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, so, big news this week from the world of, uh, Elon Musk and space. Starlink, his satellite internet project, is in the headlines again.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Elon Musks SpaceX won $885.5 million in subsidies from the Federal Communications Commission Monday to provide rural areas with high-speed internet through its Starlink satellite project, a major win for the Musk-led company and its first publicly announced major customer.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and it's kind of a head-scratcher, isn't it? Like, they lost an FCC bid, but they're still committing almost nine hundred million dollars?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and it's kind of a head-scratcher, isn't it? Like, they lost an F C C bid, but they're still committing almost nine hundred million dollars?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Elon Musks SpaceX won $885.5 million in subsidies from the Federal Communications Commission Monday to provide rural areas with high-speed internet through its Starlink satellite project, a major win for the Musk-led company...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right! Eight hundred eighty-five point five million, to be exact. To provide high-speed internet to urban areas. And the article calls it a 'devastating loss.'
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right! Eight hundred eighty-five point five million, to be exact. To provide high-speed internet to urban areas. And the article calls it a devastating loss.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Elon Musks SpaceX won $885.5 million in subsidies from the Federal Communications Commission Monday to provide rural areas with high-speed internet through its Starlink satellite project, a major win for the Musk-led company...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: A devastating loss, yeah. And, uh, for their first publicly announced major customer, apparently. Which... [overlaps]
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A devastating loss, yeah. And, uh, for their first publicly announced major customer, apparently. Which...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Elon Musks SpaceX won $885.5 million in subsidies from the Federal Communications Commission Monday to provide rural areas with high-speed internet through its Starlink satellite project, a major win for the Musk-led company and its first publicly announced major customer.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Wait, but they have Microsoft, don't they? For Azure?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wait, but they have Microsoft, don't they? For Azure?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The government is Starlinks first publicly-announced major customer, in addition to its partnership with Microsoft to provide its Azure cloud computing services over the network.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That's true, they do. But this FCC thing was supposed to be like a, you know, a solid, government-backed anchor customer. According to Caleb Henry, a senior analyst, this is a disaster because they've, uh, lost that anchor.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's true, they do. But this F C C thing was supposed to be like a, you know, a solid, government-backed anchor customer. According to Caleb Henry, a senior analyst, this is a disaster because they've, uh, lost that anchor.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This is great for SpaceX because now they have an anchor customer, Quilty Analytics senior analyst Caleb Henry told CNBC. Up until this point SpaceX has not announced any major customers ... and [this auction] provides them an assured source of revenue that they can build on as long as they meet the FCCs criteria.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Wow. So, this whole bid, it was about subsidies, right? For disincentivizing private companies in underserved areas?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow. So, this whole bid, it was about subsidies, right? For disincentivizing private companies in underserved areas?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: SpaceX was one of 180 companies who won a portion of FCC subsidies doled out via an auction to incentivize private companies to build out their networks in underserved areas of the country.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And Starlink, they weren't even among the top four bidders by dollar amount in the auction, which is pretty wild. They were, like, the only satellite operator there, though.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And Starlink, they weren't even among the top four bidders by dollar amount in the auction, which is pretty wild. They were, like, the only satellite operator there, though.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: SpaceX was the only satellite operator among the top four bidders by dollar amount... the only other satellite company to win subsidies in the auction, Maryland-based Hughes Network Systems, won $1.3 million serving 3,678 locations in one state.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: That's interesting. So they're still going to reach, what, over six hundred thousand locations across thirty-five states? Even without winning the main subsidies?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's interesting. So they're still going to reach, what, over six hundred thousand locations across thirty-five states? Even without winning the main subsidies?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The FCC says the money will allow SpaceXs Starlink project to reach 35 states across 642,925 locations...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: That's the plan, yeah. Compared to the only other satellite company that *did* win some subsidies, Hughes Network Systems, which got, like, one point three million for just under four thousand locations in one state.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's the plan, yeah. Compared to the only other satellite company that did win some subsidies, Hughes Network Systems, which got, like, one point three million for just under four thousand locations in one state.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...the only other satellite company to win subsidies in the auction, Maryland-based Hughes Network Systems, won $1.3 million serving 3,678 locations in one state.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, man, that's a huge difference! So, uh, they're really pushing ahead regardless.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, man, that's a huge difference! So, uh, they're really pushing ahead regardless.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and it makes sense when you think about the bigger picture, too. Like, rural internet access is such a, um, a crucial issue, especially now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and it makes sense when you think about the bigger picture, too. Like, rural internet access is such a, um, a crucial issue, especially now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Lack of internet access, especially in rural areas, has become of increasing concern during the pandemic.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. And, you know, they're not the only ones. Amazon's Project Kuiper is also, like, aiming for the same market, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. And, you know, they're not the only ones. Amazon's Project Kuiper is also, like, aiming for the same market, right?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A number of private companies are launching their own satellites into low-earth orbit in a bid to dominate the commercial space market, including Amazon with its satellite internet program Project Kuiper.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, for sure. It's getting pretty crowded in low-earth orbit with all these, uh, satellite internet ambitions.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, for sure. It's getting pretty crowded in low-earth orbit with all these, uh, satellite internet ambitions.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, it's a loss in one sense, but still a massive investment and commitment in another. It's, uh, pretty classic Musk, I guess.

dialogue_turns.text: Pretty classic Musk, yeah. Just, uh, another wrinkle in the whole Starlink saga.
